summary:
On leaving Europol in spring 2012 I ended 30 years of formal employment in the British Army, the British Police, the UN and the EU. Considering myself too young to retire, I embarked upon a second career as a self-employed consultant.

During my working life the world has changed dramatically and so has international cooperation in law enforcement. There have been enormous changes in intelligence-led law enforcement, especially in emerging and post-conflict states. I have witnessed all these changes. Many of them affected my daily work. Some of them created real challenges. A few of them I even directly shaped myself.

In parallel, in emerging from conflict, many of these same States have to call to account those responsible for serious human rights and criminal violations committed during that time. My previous military experience, and my more recent human rights education thus provide the complement by which my law-enforcement experience becomes applicable in this field as well.

This experience, and the skills & knowledge I gained from it, is the stock with which I now trade; I am always seeking new work opportunities where I can bring this stock to market, including through my Linked-In network. 

My aim is to have satisfied clients who return with future business, and who refer me on to their own contacts.

profile_positions.description:
I bring the experience gained during a 30-year military and law-enforcement career to the fight to suppress international crimes, these being;
- Atrocity crimes which violate International Criminal Law, namely genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes; my particular expertise is with regard to the warring factions involved in the conflict and the broader military context within which IHL violations occur. I produce data-collection plans, faction briefings, perpetrator profiles and provide training in these skills to the investigators, analysts and civil-society activists who are engaged in the documentation of IHL violations .
          - My clients to date have included the ICC, UN OHCHR (Commissions of Inquiry for Sri Lanka, South Sudan and Syria), ‘No Peace Without Justice’, ICTY, STL, IIMM and IICI. I have worked on the conflicts in Georgia, Kenya, Libya, Palestine, Syria, South-Sudan, Sri Lanka and recently Myanmar where I was engaged as the military advisor to the International Investigative Mechanism. 

- Trans-national Organised Crime which operates cross-border thereby requiring an international response. My particular expertise is in the application of the modern intelligence-led policing approach, which  I help clients to develop and implement, particularly through the establishment of appropriate organisational structures & information management processes, and the delivery of on-site training seminars. I also support clients in all key phases of the project lifecycle, including the bidding process, grant-application, content development, activity delivery and final evaluation. 
          - Clients do date have included Europol, Eurojust, CEPOL, UNODC, OSCE, ICMPD and the EU ESDP missions and projects.  This work has taken me to such places as Afghanistan, Australia, Canada, all the Former Soviet Union Republics, The Former Yugoslavia, Ghana, the Philippines and Vietnam.

profile_positions.description: Cross-Departmental management of the project giving Europol a key role in the development and delivery of the new EU policy cycle against international organised crime on behalf of the EU Standing Committee on Internal Security, including the development and specification of the new EMPACT project approach.
profile_positions.title: Project Manager - New EU Policy Cycle for Serious and Organised International Crime

profile_positions.description: Established and ran the Intelligence Centre that complemented the newly created 24/7 ‘Intelligence Cross-Roads’ by exploiting the intelligence that entered Europol by this route. This involved creating the processes for evaluating the relevance of intel for existing Europol projects, identifying new trends and developments in EU organised crime activity and providing data against which the efficiency of Europol resource deployments could be evaluated, all of which was provided as a regular briefing to senior management. As a side project, I co-designed the structure and wrote the content for the "Europol e-Learning course" the first such course launched by CEPOL.
profile_positions.title: Operations Center Intelligence Officer

profile_positions.location: Albania, Bosnia Hercegovina, Croatia, Macedonia, Montenegro, Serbia & Kosovo
profile_positions.description: Responsible for the coordination of Europol’s operational and developmental activities with the countries of the Western Balkans. This involved creating the relationships in-country, evaluation of intelligence structures and providing upgrade advice and training. I was then the operational interface between investigation unit activities in the WB and the operational support units in Europol. Through similar work with the Baltic Sea Task Force and the South East Europe Cooperation Initiative (SECI) I developed the ‘Regional Support Officer’ which is now employed widely within Europol.
profile_positions.title: Coordinator, Western Balkans. Serious Crime Department.

profile_positions.description: This wide-ranging project expanded the operational profile of Europol to allow it to deal with money laundering and to cooperate with non-EU states, as well as fixing a number of long-running problems stemming from the original Europol Convention.  Following the Prince 2 methodology I specified the work-packages, tasked them out to the relevant units across the whole structure of Europol, then managed the time & quality of each deliverable. The initiation of so many new work elements also raised a considerable 'change management' requirement. The project was delivered on time and fully accepted by the Project Board.
profile_positions.title: Project Manager, 3 Protocols Project

profile_positions.description: Coordinated the technical, legal and procedural aspects of the portfolio of Analysis Workfiles run within the SCD, including evaluation of ongoing activity, development of new approaches and opening of new AWFs, IT support tools, data protection responsibility and outreach to partner States/Agencies to secure their involvement.
profile_positions.title: Operational Analysis Coordinator

profile_positions.description:
Managed the analytical function in a number of different Analysis Workfiles combating illegal migration, Russian Mafia and on-line child pornography. Development and delivery of the Europol Strategic Analysis course and providing operational analysis training for newly recruited analysts.

Subsequently I was the first "Allocated Analyst" assigned to work within a specialist crime unit to provide the analytical interface between the Analysis Unit and SC3 (Illegal Immigration & THB Unit) such that SC3 projects would enjoy the level of analytical support required, including responsibility for developing, implementing and managing the intelligence function within SC3.
